newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore naphtha premium soars on prompt squeeze.
newsitem.headline: Singapore naphtha premium soars on prompt squeeze.

text.p: Naphtha premiums in Singapore have doubled in less than a month due to strong regional demand from petrochemical producers and a squeeze on supplies following the shutdown of refinery units, traders said on Monday.
Naphtha premiums have risen to more than $1.00 per barrel from about 40 cents after unexpected prompt purchases by several companies seeking to optimise petrochemical production.
Traders said the outlook for naptha was bullish for another couple of months. The high premium would be supported, but it might struggle to get much higher than $1.00.

The latest surge was first seen in June, when Thailand's Aromatics (Thailand) Plc stepped in to buy three or four incremental spot cargoes to cover for problems at a condensate unit, which normally provides the feedstock.
Thai Aromatics had to switch feedstock and use naphtha instead for the production of the aromatics, traders said.
Subsequently, South Korea entered the market to buy several cargoes of full-range naphtha in preparation for the start-up of a 40,000 barrel-per-day naphtha splitter.
The unit, owned by Samsung General Chemicals Co, is expected to start-up by the end of this month, a company official said.
Incremental demand was also seen from Singapore due to the higher-than-expected operation of the new 515,000 tonne per year (tpy) ethylene plant.

The unit was initially expected to operate at between 70 and 80 percent of capacity due to the late start-up of a 200,000-tpy polyethylene plant, but output was raised to 100 percent due to strong demand for ethylene in the spot market.

The Petrochemical Corporation of Singapore, 50:50 joint venture between Royal Dutch Shell and a consortium of Japanese companies led by Sumitomo Chemical Co Ltd, started up the new ethylene unit at the end of April.
Traders said demand was also boosted by the start up Thai Petrochemical Industry's of a 350,000 tpy ethylene plant in April.
The start up of these new plants has put downward pressure on ethylene prices but producers were still enjoying a good margin, ensuring output would be maintained at a high level, traders said.
"Naphtha demand will be strong for another month or so because of the high prices of ethylene," one trader said.
Spot ethylene prices slid by around $80 per tonne to just under $550 from a month ago but is still high enough to give producers a margin of about $200 per tonne, traders said.
Firmer premiums were also due to a cut in supplies from Indonesia due to the shutdown of a crude unit at the Balikpapan refinery since July 10.
The refinery generally exports three 240,000-barrel cargoes of naphtha a month, traders said.
Indonesian naphtha exports would be low in August as well because a crude unit at the Cilacap refinery will close from August 13 for about 35 days, traders said.
The tighter regional supplies were also aggravated by cuts in refining output in Singapore due to poor margins and high stocks of middle distillates.
Currently, about 90,000-bpd of production is lost as a result of these cuts, traders said.
-- Singapore Newsroom (+65 870 3093)
